symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Mucositis due to Chemotherapy or Radiation Therapy

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue, leading to inflammation and damage to various body systems. Symptoms can include rash, joint pain, and kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but may also cause systemic issues such as mood changes, bone loss, and increased risk of infection.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory type of arthritis associated with psoriasis, characterized by joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, along with skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) impairs the immune system by attacking T cells, leading to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS), which significantly increases susceptibility to infections and certain types of cancer.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Symptoms can include rash, flu-like symptoms, joint pain, and neurological problems.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include fatigue, weight loss, skin rashes, and pain in the bones.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that forms in plasma cells, causing bone pain, weakened bones, increased susceptibility to infections, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause rashes, organ dysfunction, and pain. Depending on the type, it can affect various organs.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It can increase the perception of pain.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood or bone marrow characterized by an abnormal increase in white blood cells. Symptoms can include bone pain, fatigue, fever, and an increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, and can cause complications such as hypersomnolence and basophilia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the bone marrow but often moves to the blood. It can lead to an increased number of white blood cells, some of which are basophils. Symptoms may include tiredness and occasional nausea.

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which abnormal blood cells and fibers build up in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia and thrombocytosis. It can cause symptoms like hypersomnolence and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Erythrocytosis
diagnoses.description: An increase in red blood cells due to an underlying condition such as hypoxia, tumor production of erythropoietin, or endocrine abnormalities. It can be associated with hypersomnolence and polycythemia but less commonly with basophilia.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing or periods of shallow breathing during sleep. It can lead to excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomnolence) and, in some cases, might be indirectly associated with polycythemia due to chronic hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function. It can lead to increased levels of certain types of cells in the blood due to the body's attempt to compensate for the lack of erythropoietin, leading to symptoms like nausea and possibly secondary polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. This can lead to an increased sensitivity to cold, fatigue, and potential disturbances in sleep patterns such as hypersomnolence.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A group of lung diseases that block airflow and make it difficult to breathe, leading to hypoxia and secondary polycythemia. Patients may also experience fatigue and sleep disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin, bone marrow, and internal organs. It can cause symptoms like nausea, flushing, and hypersensitivity to physical stimuli.

diagnoses.name: Heavy Metal Poisoning (e.g., Lead or Mercury)
diagnoses.description: Exposure to heavy metals can lead to various symptoms, including nausea, fatigue, and neurological symptoms. Chronic exposure may indirectly affect blood cell counts, leading to symptoms associated with polycythemia or basophilia as the body tries to compensate for oxygen transport.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with Normal Pulmonary Function Tests in Early Stages

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (considering non-obstructive patterns)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor occurs when abnormal cells form within the brain. It can be malignant (cancerous) or benign (noncancerous).

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system).

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache characterized by severe pain, often accompanied by nausea, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord.

diagnoses.name: Brain abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus that develops in response to an infection or trauma in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. It is often caused by a viral infection.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood flow to the brain.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: This condition involves bleeding within the brain tissue itself, often caused by hypertension, vascular malformations, or head injuries.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar insufficiency
diagnoses.description: Vertebrobasilar insufficiency is a condition in which blood flow to the back of the brain is limited, often due to blockage or narrowing of arteries.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor occurs when abnormal cells form within the brain. There are two main types of tumors: malignant or cancerous tumors and benign tumors.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraine is a powerful headache that often happens with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light. It can last hours or days.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to your brain.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Meningitis can result from viruses, bacteria, trauma, or fungi.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain. It can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain (hemorrhagic stroke).

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, spread by ticks. It can cause neurological problems, including meningitis, facial palsy, and neuropathy.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by autoimmunity causing a wide array of symptoms including malar rash and hemolytic anemia; while systemic involvement can contribute to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.rationale: A specific diagnosis where the immune system attacks red blood cells, leading to hemolytic anemia; systemic effects may contribute to other symptoms indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.rationale: A genetic disorder causing abnormal blood vessel formation (telangiectasia); associated with anemia, though typically not classified as hemolytic.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Shares features with several autoimmune diseases including lupus, and can present with hemolytic anemia, rashes, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: A group of autoimmune diseases that may cause skin changes like telangiectasias and systemic symptoms, potentially affecting the brain and causing delirium.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting joints, RA can have systemic manifestations including skin changes and, rarely, hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia, with potential for systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder that can lead to clot formation and miscarriage; may present with hemolytic anemia and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria
diagnoses.rationale: A rare, acquired, life-threatening disease of the blood characterized by destruction of red blood cells, bone marrow failure, and thrombosis.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily involves thrombocytopenia but can present alongside autoimmune hemolytic anemia in the Evans syndrome; systemic involvement may lead to a broad range of symptoms including neurological ones.

diagnoses: Lupus Erythematosus with Secondary Sjögren's Syndrome
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
